The Impact of Severe Storms across the US

Mar 12, 2022

By WILLIAM DAY

As global climate change brings more severe weather more frequently, areas around the United States will experience this change differently. Between 2010 and 2020, the National Oceanographic and Atmospheric Association catalogued 110,394 severe weather events across the country, accounting for over $245 billion in property damage.

Flooding occurs nationwide, but is concentrated along coasts and major waterways

Tornadoes and wind damage also affect much of the US, but especially the Midwest and South

Hurricanes are geographically isolated, but result in catastrophic property damage

Several counties in Texas, Louisiana, and Florida suffered over $15.2 billion in hurricane-caused property damage during the last decade

Wildfires appear sporadically, but are often found in Texas, along the Rockies, and on the west coast

Between 2010 and 2020, Washington, California, and Texas all experienced their largest wildfires in state history.
